lines.content: This is a chatbot built based on the Project Duke template. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
What can I do for you?
1. Copy the jar file into an empty folder.
2. Open a command window in that folder.
3. Run the command `java -jar {filename}.jar` e.g., `java -jar Duke.jar` (i.e., run the command in the same folder as the jar file).
Enter a line of text adds the item to the list. You should see something like the below as the output:
Now you have 1 tasks in the list.
1. `list`: print all existing tasks in the list.
2. `mark INDEX_NUMBER`: mark the task indicated by the index as Done:
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
3. `unmark INDEX_NUMBER`: mark the task indicated by the index as Not Done:
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 2 tasks in the list.
5. `deadline DESCRIPTION [/by DUE_DATE]`: add a task that need to be done before a specific date/time.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 3 tasks in the list.
6. `event DESCRIPTION [/from START_DATE] [/to END_DATE]`: add a task that start at a specific date/time and ends at a specific date/time.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
7. `delete INDEX_NUMBER`: remove the task indicated by the index from the list.
8. `bye`: exit the program. You should see something like the below as the output:
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
Words in UPPER_CASE are the parameters to be supplied by the user.
e.g. in `add n/NAME`, `NAME` is a parameter which can be used as add n/John Doe.
Items in square brackets are optional.
e.g `n/NAME [t/TAG]` can be used as `n/John Doe t/friend` or as `n/John Doe`.
Extraneous parameters for commands that do not take in parameters (such as `help`, `list`, `exit` and `clear`) will be ignored.
e.g. if the command specifies `help 123`, it will be interpreted as `help`.
This is a chatbot built based on the Project Duke template. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
What can I do for you?
1. Copy the jar file into an empty folder.
2. Open a command window in that folder.
3. Run the command `java -jar {filename}.jar` e.g., `java -jar Duke.jar` (i.e., run the command in the same folder as the jar file).
Enter a line of text adds the item to the list. You should see something like the below as the output:
Now you have 1 tasks in the list.
1. `list`: print all existing tasks in the list.
2. `mark INDEX_NUMBER`: mark the task indicated by the index as Done:
Nice! I've marked this task as done:
3. `unmark INDEX_NUMBER`: mark the task indicated by the index as Not Done:
OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 2 tasks in the list.
5. `deadline DESCRIPTION [/by DUE_DATE]`: add a task that need to be done before a specific date/time.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 3 tasks in the list.
6. `event DESCRIPTION [/from START_DATE] [/to END_DATE]`: add a task that start at a specific date/time and ends at a specific date/time.
Got it. I've added this task:
Now you have 4 tasks in the list.
7. `delete INDEX_NUMBER`: remove the task indicated by the index from the list.
8. `bye`: exit the program. You should see something like the below as the output:
Bye. Hope to see you again soon!
Words in UPPER_CASE are the parameters to be supplied by the user.
e.g. in `add n/NAME`, `NAME` is a parameter which can be used as add n/John Doe.
Items in square brackets are optional.
e.g `n/NAME [t/TAG]` can be used as `n/John Doe t/friend` or as `n/John Doe`.
Extraneous parameters for commands that do not take in parameters (such as `help`, `list`, `exit` and `clear`) will be ignored.
e.g. if the command specifies `help 123`, it will be interpreted as `help`.

public static void throwNoDescriptionException() throws NoDescriptionException {
* Perform different operations to the task list according to different user inputs.
* Monitoring user input, print and update the list of tasks constantly
* Stop only when user input equals to "bye".

* Returns a list of tasks that have description matched with the input line of string.
* @param toFind The input string to compare with.
* @param allTasks All tasks stored in the list.
public static ArrayList<Task> matchedTasks(String toFind, ArrayList<Task> allTasks) {
* Represents an add command where a new task is added to the existing list of task.

* If the position is unset, NaN is returned.

* @param textToAdd The line of text to write to the file.
* @param ifAppend Indicate if append the text at the end of the file (true)
* @throws IOException If file is not found at the indicated file path.
private static void writeToFile(String filePath, String textToAdd, boolean ifAppend) throws IOException {
public static void updateFile(String inputText, boolean ifAppend) {

* Returns 0 if the file is not found.

* Add the identified tasks into a list of existing tasks.
* @param fileToRead The file to read from.
public static void readFromFile(File fileToRead, ArrayList<Task> existTasks) {
* A class that deals with loading tasks from the file and saving tasks in the file.

* If user did not put any valid task description.
public static void checkDescription(String[] userInputWords) throws
* Returns a new TaskList.Task that is either of a special type (toDo, event, deadline)
* @param description Text input by the user.
* @return A task with a special type or a task with description
* "Not special task" but no special type.
* Represents a command to delete a task form an existing list of tasks.
* Delete a task from the stored list based on the user input.
* @param userInputWords The task to be printed.
public static void delete(String[] userInputWords, ArrayList<Task> tasks) {
PrintText.printWithLinebreak("Please enter a valid item to delete.");
* String description represents the textual description given to the task.
* boolean isDone represents the complete status of the task.
* char type represents the task type toDo, event, deadline or none of them.
* Construct a new task with the specified description, type and isDone status.
* @param type TaskList.Task type toDo, event, deadline or none of them.
* @param isDone Indicate if the task is marked as done.
public Task(String description, char type, boolean isDone) {
* Returns the status icon assigned to the task.
* Icon should be "X" if the task is done and " " if not done.
* Returns the type icon assigned to the task.
* Icon equals to the attribute type.
* Update the task description to a new one.
* @param newDescription New description given to the task.
* A class that contains the task list e.g., it has operations to add/delete tasks in the list.
public static void deleteTask(String[] userInputWords, ArrayList<Task> tasks) {
* Represents a command to print one or multiple tasks to the screen and file.
* Print all the tasks stored in the list.
PrintText.print("Here are the tasks in your list:");

* @param index The task index to be written in the file.
* @param ifAppend Indicate if append the text at the end of the file (true)
public static void printToFile(Task input, int index, boolean ifAppend) {
* Print multiple tasks to the file at path FILENAME.
* @param ifAppend Indicate if append the text at the end of the file (true)
public static void printMultipleToFile(ArrayList<Task> tasks, boolean ifAppend) {
* Print out the task with special type, toDo, event, or deadline.
* TaskList.Task description is updated to the proper format.
* @param newTask The task to be printed.
* @param taskNum Total number of tasks in the list.
public static void specialTask(Task newTask, int taskNum) {

* Represents a command to print a line of text to the screen.
* String LINEBREAK represents line break to be printed when required.
* @param text The input text to be printed.
* Print a line of text along with one line break above and another below.
* @param text The input text to be printed.
* A class that deals with interactions with the user.
* Greet the user when the program starts.
* @param botName The name of the chatbot.
* Say goodbye to the user when exit the program.
PrintText.printWithLinebreak("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
